conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their acceleration phases, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs for both particles.
The velocity-time graph shows that particle A accelerates from rest to a maximum velocity \( v \) in a time interval \( t_0 \).
The velocity-time graph shows that particle B accelerates from rest to a maximum velocity \( v \) in a time interval \( t_0 \).
The acceleration \( a_A \) for particle A can be calculated using the formula \( a = \frac{v - v_0}{t} \), where \( v \) is the final velocity and \( v_0 \) is the initial velocity.
For particle A, \( v = 2v_0 \) and \( t = t_0 \), so \( a_A = \frac{2v_0 - v_0}{t_0} = \frac{v_0}{t_0} \).
The acceleration \( a_B \) for particle B can be calculated using the formula \( a = \frac{v - v_0}{t} \), where \( v \) is the final velocity and \( v_0 \) is the initial velocity.
For particle B, \( v = 2v_0 \) and \( t = t_0 \), so \( a_B = \frac{2v_0 - v_0}{t_0} = \frac{v_0}{t_0} \).
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their acceleration phases is \( \frac{a_A}{a_B} = \frac{\frac{v_0}{t_0}}{\frac{v_0}{t_0}} = 1 \).
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their acceleration phases is \( 1:1 \).
